item.title: Ha'ånen "Liberasión"
item.description: TW/CW: Mentions of war. I can’t recall a time when my family celebrated “Liberation Day”. I can recall times that we volunteered at the Sons & Daughters of Guam Club for Liberation fiestas: cleaning, cooking, setting up & breaking down, etc…but being young, I wasn’t interested in the “whys” of fiestas. But celebrating at home? Tåya'. I’m positive there’s complexities behind that. I mean, growing up I only ever heard one story about the war from my dad’s mom.

item.title: Magof Påsgua Nochebuena 2020
item.description: Håfa adai todus hamyu yan Magof Påsgua Nochebuena para siha ni' mañilebra. Christmas time for me today has shifted mostly towards i bandan asaguå-hu. Gi minagåhet, hagas ha' hu silebra Nochebuena yan i familiå-ña. On my side of the family we tend to split time between my dad’s side and my mom’s side. Even then, those parties tend to be closer to New Years or after, i.e., my family tends to celebrate Christmas after New Years — ya maolek-ña i “sales” dispues di New Years ki antes, hunggan?

item.title: Adingani i Lahi-hu
item.description: Note: updated 2020-12-22 by removing reference to my since-deleted write.as blog. Most of the Chamoru that I’ve been using lately is towards i lahi-hu. Håcha na såkkan idåt-ña, pues inadingan-måmi ni ti mapput. I wanted to share some of those phrases with you and perhaps get some feedback. If you’re here then I’ll assume you came from Twitter, IG, or some other social media site. Feel free to hit me up on any of those.
